intro: Abutilon tiubae f. perenne, commonly known as the evergreen abutilon, is a variant of the abutilon species native to tropical regions. It is a shrub characterized by its broad, heart-shaped leaves that are typically hairy and have a velvety texture. The plant produces clusters of small, yellow flowers that bloom throughout the growing season. Its bark is fibrous and often used in traditional medicine for its purported healing properties. This plant thrives in well-drained soil and requires ample sunlight to flourish.
distribution_native_art_desc: Abutilon tiubae f. perenne is primarily native to the tropical regions of South America, particularly Brazil. It is found in the Atlantic Forest biome, which spans the eastern coast of Brazil. This plant thrives in humid, shaded environments within this ecosystem. It is commonly associated with rocky outcrops and disturbed forest areas. Due to habitat loss, it is considered a rare and endangered species in its native range.
distribution_introduced_art_desc: Abutilon tiubae f. perenne was mainly introduced to the Pacific Northwest of the United States. It was brought there as an ornamental plant due to its attractive foliage and unique appearance. The distribution is primarily limited to gardens and cultivated areas in this region. It has not established itself in the wild and is not considered invasive. This plant is commonly found in horticultural settings rather than natural habitats.
